block.p: Last Thursday, Nielsen Media Research began releasing standardized information about viewership of commercials. The numbers came as a relief to television executives, showing that viewers who own DVRs do not fast-forward through the ads as much as had been feared.

Even if they did not confirm the industry's worst expectations, however, the numbers still showed that DVR ownership affected ad viewing. For example, among all 18- to 49-year-olds who watched the real-time broadcast of ''The Office'' on May 10, about 249,000 people did not tune into the commercials, a 6.2 percent drop-off in viewership.
Numbers from Nielsen Media Research showed that viewers who own DVRs do not fast-forward through ads as much as had been feared.

Last Thursday, Nielsen Media Research began releasing standardized information about viewership of commercials. The numbers came as a relief to television executives, showing that viewers who own DVRs do not fast-forward through the ads as much as had been feared.

Even if they did not confirm the industry's worst expectations, however, the numbers still showed that DVR ownership affected ad viewing. For example, among all 18- to 49-year-olds who watched the real-time broadcast of ''The Office'' on May 10, about 249,000 people did not tune into the commercials, a 6.2 percent drop-off in viewership.

But in households that owned a DVR, commercials were skipped by 50.9 percent of those who watched the show, a figure that counts both live viewers and those who watched the show up to a week after its broadcast.

Over all, in the first week of May, the proportion of viewers who stuck around for TV commercials was 69.9 percent among 18- to 49-year-olds in households with DVRs, 24 percentage points lower than it was for real-time viewers that age in all households.

''I don't think people were shocked,'' said Brad Adgate, senior vice president for research at Horizon Media, an ad-buying agency. ''I think the industry was hanging its hat on 70 percent at some point,'' as the proportion of DVR viewers who watched commercials.
